title: Solar panels, battery storage ease electricity concerns for Adelaide Hills resident - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Adelaide Hills resident Keith Bladon is working toward taking his property off the electricity grid and is keen to frame his final power bill. 
"I started to get really upset about the way that the electricity market is privatised," he said. 
"I sat down and did some maths and realised that I could actually make a quite significant investment and get a 10-year return â€” and have autonomy and security of supply," he said. 
He is not entirely off the grid yet, as he still dips in to the power network a couple of times a year when it is too cloudy for his solar panels to work. 
Mr Bladon said a backup diesel generator was his next step. 
"What that means is that you have a party and you disconnect the power, and you frame your last electricity bill," he said. Off-grid interest spikes after blackouts 
A number of companies have sprung up in response to rising demand from property owners to rely less, or not at all, on electricity providers. One in seven homes in Australia has solar panels on their roof. But what are they and how do they work? 
Sean LePoidevin from Off Grid Energy said battery-storage technology was improving and electricity bills kept rising for households and businesses. 
"You certainly get a spike in interest after a blackout, both in South Australia and nationally," he said. 
"Over the last 12 months our interest and sales have grown by about 20 per cent each month, which is a direct correlation to price rises, blackouts and a general perception and knowledge about electricity." 
Mr Bladon said going off the grid with solar panels and battery-storage gave him peace of mind, and he urged other people to consider doing the same. 
"It's just nice to know that I've got that security and if the power does fail, I'm OK," he said.
